responses.rationale: The segment describes a limitation (limited funds) rather than a capability or preparedness measure.
Describes measures ('surveillance and control') without linking them to reassurance.
The segment describes a threat and observed impact, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes actions taken ('confirmed the H5N1 outbreak', 'analysing samples') which are response measures/safeguards.
Describes actions taken ('have buried hundreds of dead birds') which are response measures/safeguards.
Describes a condition ('unless international funding is secured') related to a potential future capability/measure.
Describes a call for action ('call for international funding to help stop the disease spreading') which relates to a future capability/measure.
Describes actions taken ('We are responding', 'provide information that assists them in mitigating') which are response measures/capabilities.
The segment describes a request for information about a capability, not the capability itself.
The segment states an opinion and describes economic impact, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes an action taken by another country (imposed restrictions).
The segment describes a case and symptoms, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a potential consequence related to trade rules, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes an action taken by another country (imposed restrictions).
The segment provides economic data, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes an action taken by another country and its economic impact.
The segment describes an action taken by another country (restricted import).
The segment provides statistics on population and prices, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes market conditions and consumer behavior, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes potential future negative impacts, not capabilities or preparedness measures.
The segment expresses concern, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment states a lack of a protective measure, not a capability or preparedness measure.
The segment states it's too early to quantify impact and expresses concern, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a mode of transmission, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes a state of preparedness/surveillance ('scientists are on guard') without linking to reassurance.
The segment describes symptoms, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes symptoms, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes symptoms and outcome for a case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical statistics, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical context, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports locations where the virus was discovered, not the surveillance capability itself.
Reports control measures taken ('been killed to stop outbreaks') which are safeguards.
The segment reports locations where the virus was detected, not the surveillance capability itself.
The segment describes the spread of the virus, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes viral evolution, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes knowledge ('known to us'), research ('studying it'), and preparedness ('preparing for avian flu for 20 years').
Describes the agency's stance ('taking bird flu seriously') and state of knowledge ('virus has already been well studied').
The segment reports developments/findings, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports outbreaks, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports developments and expert concern, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment states a goal, not a description of capabilities or preparedness measures.
Describes a measure being taken ('France has been trialling bird flu vaccines') which is a development capability/response.
Describes a rule/regulation related to a safeguard (housing measures).
Describes a condition for lifting a safeguard ('housing measures have been lifted') and a future possibility.
Describes a consequence of a safeguard (hens temporarily housed) and the reason ('to protect their health and welfare').
Describes actions taken ('supermarkets will put up signs') and a future possibility related to lifting safeguards.
Describes a rule/regulation related to a safeguard (housing) and its consequence.
Describes a safeguard ('bird flu lockdown') and its consequence.
Describes a consequence and the reason ('hens have spent the last four months cooped up') which is the safeguard.
Describes a measure taken ('in a 3-kilometre sanitary radius') and a future action ('authorities would decide on possible culling').
The segment reports cases in other countries, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports case location and count, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes a future action ('will cull nearly 140,000 turkey and chickens') which is a control measure/safeguard.
Reports control measures taken ('culling of around 400,000 chickens and ducks') which are safeguards.
Reports historical control measures ('1.67 million chickens were culled') which are safeguards.
Reports historical control measures ('91,000 chickens were culled') which are safeguards.
The segment provides population statistics, not capabilities or preparedness.
Reports control measures taken ('nearly 2 million chickens will have been culled') which are safeguards.
The segment reports discovery locations, not the surveillance capability itself.
Expresses a hopeful future possibility ('aim for some incredible game-changing interventions').
The segment expresses a personal feeling/opinion, not capabilities or preparedness.
Discusses a future possibility ('going to end it by 2030') and expresses uncertainty.
Expresses hope for future progress ('Hopefully we’ll make some inroads').
The segment expresses a personal feeling, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes a potential future possibility ('could create a path for serious control').
Describes a past action related to research capability ('included these women in the study').
Expresses a hope for a future possibility ('love to see the promise of the malaria interventions realized').
The segment asks a question, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes a plan for a future capability/resource ('want a living document', 'will have individual pages').
The segment refers to a past statement about a vision, not the vision or capability itself.
Discusses the effectiveness of a capability ('we have effective PrEP') and its limitations.
Discusses the effectiveness of a capability ('we have effective PrEP') and its limitations.
The segment describes a factor affecting uptake of a capability, not the capability itself.
Discusses focusing/investing in capabilities (vaccines, lenacapavir).
Expresses hope for future progress ('some incipient breakthroughs').
Describes progress in research/understanding ('field is getting really exciting in terms of understanding').
Describes progress in research/knowledge ('have been about four amazing papers out').
Mentions the existence of an effective capability ('existence of effective pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)').
Discusses a potential future action ('blunt the pace') and future planning ('figure out what the next phase of control can be').
The segment expresses an opinion about severity, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment states a lack of knowledge/information, not a capability or preparedness measure.
The segment uses a metaphor and states an opinion about difficulty of containment, not the capability itself.
The segment uses a metaphor, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment asks a question about the possibility of containment, not the capability itself.
The segment introduces a topic, not capabilities or preparedness.
Mentions surveillance systems ('regular surveillance systems') in the context of potential failure.
The segment expresses worry about delayed diagnosis/detection, not a capability or preparedness measure.
Mentions a specific surveillance system ('sentinel surveillance') and expresses concern about its limitations.
Mentions a specific surveillance system ('sentinel surveillance') and expresses concern about its limitations.
The segment expresses worry and reports findings, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment discusses potential spread, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment asks a question, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment discusses reluctance to raise an alarm, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment discusses past trauma, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment discusses past trauma, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment discusses past trauma, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment expresses reluctance to repeat a past experience, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment expresses a personal thought, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes past events and social interactions, not capabilities or preparedness measures.
The segment describes a social/political climate and a limitation on implementing a safeguard.
The segment describes a social/political climate, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes an action taken regarding assessment ('kept their assessment... fairly constant') which is part of surveillance/analysis capability.
Describes an effort/approach ('effort to be really cautious') related to preparedness/response strategy.
The segment expresses a personal feeling, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment asks a question to introduce a topic, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a change in communication strategy, not a public health capability or safeguard.
The segment describes a past state of affairs, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment expresses an opinion about past communication failures, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment expresses an opinion using a metaphor, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides personal background information, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes actions related to organizational function, not public health capabilities.
The segment describes a past situation regarding budget cuts and political sentiment, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a past situation regarding budget cuts, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a personal priority related to organizational function, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a job function, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes the history and reputation of an institute, not its current capabilities.
The segment reports a statement about interview preferences, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a personal process, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment discusses sources of information, not capabilities or preparedness measures themselves.
The segment expresses willingness to discuss a topic, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides context about the interview, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes topics of an interview including 'hopes for NIAID' which relate to future possibilities/capabilities.
The segment describes actions related to organizational function, not public health capabilities.
The segment provides biographical information and historical context, not capabilities or preparedness.
Suggests a future action ('should also find funds') related to capability/resource allocation.
The segment describes a support measure (compensation), not a public health capability against the disease.
The segment describes a potential future policy response, not a public health capability against the disease.
The segment describes an economic consequence, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment predicts a future negative impact, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes a current negative condition/risk, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports expert concern, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports observed impact, not surveillance capability itself.
The segment describes a factor affecting transmission, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical context about the outbreak, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes the spread mechanism, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes the impact, not capabilities or preparedness.
Reports control measures taken ('Farmers have culled millions') which are safeguards.
Describes actions taken ('took action to control', 'ordering... to be confined indoors') which are safeguards.
The segment discusses the status of Covid, not bird flu capabilities or preparedness.
Suggests components of a response ('should include targeted conservation funding') related to capability/resource allocation.
Expresses a future possibility regarding knowledge acquisition ('we’ll know in the weeks ahead') related to surveillance/understanding.
The segment asks a question about potential impact, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment asks a question about transmission mechanism, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment asks a question about transmission route, not capabilities or preparedness.

Gives advice ('I would surely avoid') which is a public health measure/guidance.
Gives advice ('I would surely avoid') which is a public health measure/guidance.

The segment asks a question about transmission route, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes a method of investigation/surveillance ('looking at the epidemiology').
Asks a question about surveillance/monitoring ('Are scientists watching H5N1 closely').
Describes a hypothetical scenario involving detection ('start picking up additional human cases') which is part of surveillance capability.
The segment asks a question about detection methods, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment discusses the source of exposure for a case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment asks and answers a question about the source of exposure for a case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment asks a question about the source of exposure for a case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports a finding from an investigation, not the investigation capability itself.
The segment describes the biological mechanism of infection and severity, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment gives advice about personal vigilance, not institutional capabilities or preparedness.
Gives advice about monitoring ('you have to keep your eye on it') which is related to surveillance/capability.
The segment provides historical context and a past prediction, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical context, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical context, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment states a historical perspective, not capabilities or preparedness.

Identifies a potential sentinel species ('pigs would be the animal species... sentinel') for surveillance strategy.
The segment provides historical context and risk assessment, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment contains active reassurance ('low risk') which prevents it from being a Q8 'yes'.
The segment asks a question about likelihood of spread, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes circumstances of a past case and testing ('someone who was tested routinely').
The segment describes who was interviewed and the topics, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical context and compares virus forms, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes a past case and testing method ('tested positive for the virus via a nasal swab').
Reports case count and describes a past case and testing method ('tested positive for the virus via a nasal swab').
The segment reports case count, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment contains active reassurance ('risk to the public remains low') which prevents it from being a Q8 'yes'.
The segment reports locations where infections were found, not the surveillance capability itself.
The segment reports species infected, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes treatment ('being treated with antiviral medication') which is a capability/intervention.
The segment reports a case and confirming authority, not the testing/surveillance capability itself.
Describes ongoing action ('conducting ongoing tests') and guidance ('has cautioned against consuming raw milk') which are surveillance/safeguards and public health measures.
Describes ongoing research ('continue to confirm') and the effectiveness of a safeguard (pasteurization inactivates virus).
Describes a potential future use for a resource ('could potentially be used to inoculate') which is a capability.
Describes a future possibility regarding availability of a resource ('could be available as early as this month') which is a capability.
Describes the process/timeline for manufacturing a capability ('can take four to six months').
Describes the technology used in a capability ('use messenger RNA').
Describes a future possibility regarding communication about a capability ('expects to have more announcements').
Describes ongoing discussions about a potential strategy ('robust discussions are occurring') related to planning/preparedness.
The segment contains active reassurance ('risk to the general public from bird flu remains low') which prevents it from being a Q8 'yes'.
The segment reports expert concern and describes a potential future negative outcome, not capabilities or preparedness.
States uncertainty about a future capability/resource ('too early to tell how many doses Moderna will be able to manufacture').
Describes features of a contract related to accelerating development of a capability ('options to accelerate the development timeline').
Describes the focus of a future trial ('would likely focus on safety and immune response') related to capability development.
Describes a recommendation for future actions/strategies ('recommended rapid implementation of risk mitigation and surveillance strategies').
The segment reports findings/statistics from surveillance, not the surveillance capability itself.
The segment describes the scope and impact of the epidemic, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes a risk assessment ('likely at higher risk') which is a capability, without linking it to reassurance.
The segment describes transmission routes, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes the nature of the threat and reasons for concern, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment states the need for action, not a description of the action or capability itself.
The segment states the need for an action and warns of negative outcome if it fails, not the capability itself.
Describes a potential detection method ('wastewater signal') which is a capability.
The segment uses a metaphor to describe difficulty of detection, not the capability itself.
The segment describes factors making detection difficult, not the capability itself.
The segment describes viral evolution and potential future outcome, not capabilities or preparedness.
Suggests a future action ('a thorough recounting... would help clarify') related to investigation capability.
The segment expresses an opinion about credibility, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment comments on the tone of communication, not the communication capability itself.
The segment comments on the tone of communication, not the communication capability itself.
Describes what epidemiologists can do ('can get a lot of information') which is an epidemiology capability.
The segment reports criticism of information flow and lack of details, not the capability itself.
The segment reports a lack of identification/information, not the capability itself.
Describes a hospital instituting precautions ('hospital instituted precautions') and workers not being tested.
Describes an action taken by the CDC ('added four more health care workers to the list') which is part of case tracking capability.
Describes a disclosure by the CDC ('the C.D.C. disclosed') which is part of communication/information sharing capability.
The segment expresses a personal feeling contingent on a future event, not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes the concept of sentinel cases ('health care workers have often been the sentinel cases') which is part of surveillance strategy.
The segment describes a potential future negative outcome (overwhelm), not capabilities or preparedness.
Describes an action taken ('patient was tested') and the context ('routine flu surveillance') which are capabilities.
